Yes, the city of New York has implemented several programs aimed at reducing crime rates among youth. These programs have been successful in reducing juvenile delinquency and repeat offenses among young people by providing education, employment opportunities, and support services. Some of these programs include:

1. Youth Employment Services: This program provides summer and year-round paid employment to young people aged between 14 and 24 who are from underserved communities. 

2. Beacon Community Centers: This program provides education, recreational activities, social services, and other programs to young people outside of regular school hours. It aims to provide safe, inclusive spaces for young people to engage in positive activities.

3. The New York City Youth Violence Reduction Strategy: This strategy employs a public health approach to reducing youth violence, utilizing data-driven interventions such as violence prevention and intervention programs, mental health and counseling services, and alternative to incarceration programs.

4. Cure Violence Youth: This initiative focuses on reducing gun violence among young people in high-risk communities through employing "violence interrupters" to mediate conflicts and provide counseling and resources for those at risk of violent activity.

These programs and others have been successful in preventing young people from getting caught up in the criminal justice system, offering them alternatives and opportunities to improve their lives.
